shared_text:
Dawn Buckingham

Recently I was able to visit with Lampasas ISD Superintendent Dr. Chane Rascoe on how they were preparing and adjusting daily to facilitate in person learning at Lampasas ISD schools. Thank you and your faculty for all of the hard work that has gone into a successful start to the school year.

If your child is delinquent on immunizations, please drop off the current list of immunizations to your child's campus as soon as possible. Immunization requirements are for all students (on campus learners, and remote learners). Delinquent vaccinations can delay the student from obtaining his/her schedule or even starting school. You may view and print your child's immunization record from the health tab in Family Access. You can also email nurse@lisdtx.org, contact campus nurses starting Aug 3rd, or contact your child’s healthcare provider. Because we are not having Meet the Teacher night this year, the nurses will be at each campus on August 6, 2020 from 4 pm – 6 pm for you to drop off your child’s medications if they will be taking any this year. It will be a drive through drop-off at each campus, except for Taylor Creek Elementary. They will have a table to walk-up to outside. You may also drop off your child’s updated immunization record (if delinquent) to prevent a delay in getting their schedule. Thank you!

https://dshs.texas.gov/immunize/school/default.shtm

Did you know? Today is Earth Day 2020!
Earth Day was a unified response to an environment in crisis — oil spills, smog, rivers so polluted they literally caught fire.
On April 22, 1970, 20 million Americans — 10% of the U.S. population at the time — took to the streets, college campuses and hundreds of cities to protest environmental ignorance and demand a new way forward for our planet.
The first Earth Day is credited with launching the modern environmental movement, and is now recognized as the planet’s largest civic event.

How can you celebrate Earth Day?
On Earth Day, take a walk or run through the neighborhood. Go alone and relish your solitude, enjoying the time for free thought or listening to a podcast. Or take advantage of the opportunity for quality time with your loved ones and stroll with your family and dog by your side. There are so many things you can do with your family, on Earth Day.
It's safe to do so if you make sure you keep your distance from other people outside of your family.
